title: HW5 Q1
content: Context: This is an old exam problem that asks you to think about convolutional layers from a different angle. First, you will be asked to derive the filter itself from output and input. Second, you will need to understand how the idea of convolutional filters can be used for upsampling (this is called "transpose convolutions") instead of the downsampling. This is important to understand as we may not get much coverage of transpose convolutions in this course.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>In the classical definition of a convolution (used in signal processing), the filter is flipped before being applied to each chunk of inputs -- this would result in an output of [az, ay, ax+bz, by, bx+cz, cy, cx] in our example. In machine learning land, we tend to not do this as it simplifies the operation.</paragraph></document>

comments.content: The way I thought about it was it's applying the kernel in a larger-sized version of the input:the 2x2 kernel is not flipped in any position, but for the -1 in the input, the kernel is placed in the top left corner, because that's where the -1 is in the input. The new matrix is 3x3 because the stride is 1. Similarly for the other values in the input, the kernel is placed in their respective positions, but the kernel itself is still the same 2x2 that is not flipped.
